channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Fitness Wearable Company Whoop Raises $200 Million at a $3.6 Billion Valuation
item.description: Startups like Oura and Biofourmis, which both make wearable sensors, have also secured major funding over the past two years.  Google completed a $2.1 billion deal this year to purchase the fitness-tracking company Fitbit. — SQ
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 31
item.description: (Eater)  Read: Margaritaville and the myth of American leisure. She found the gesture non-fungible.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: China Limits Online Video Games to Three Hours a Week for Minors
item.description: All online video games are required to be connected to an “anti-addiction” system operated by the NPPA using real-name registration. The Chinese government banned kids under 18 from playing online video games on school nights and will allow gaming for only one hour a day on weekends and public holidays. — SQ
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: EU Recommends Banning Unvaccinated American Tourists From Traveling to Europe
item.description: The European Council removed the US from the “safe list” of countries that can send tourists to the EU due to high Covid rates here in the States. While the EU opened up its borders to American tourists in June, the US has yet to reciprocate for European visitors, angering the EU.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What You Need to Know About Elizabeth Holmes’s Trial That Starts Today
item.description: Here’s a quick timeline for everyone who was too young or busy in the aughts: 2003: At the age of 19, Elizabeth Holmes dropped out of Stanford and started Theranos with the goal of revolutionizing blood testing. Jury selection begins today for the criminal fraud trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of shuttered Silicon Valley biotech startup Theranos. Holmes’s net worth also grew to $4.5 billion, good enough for No. 1 on the Forbes list of America’s Richest Self-Made Women. From there, investors started suing for fraud, the government yanked the company’s blood-testing license, and in September 2018, the SEC dissolved Theranos. — MM
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Fitness Wearable Company Whoop Raises $200 Million at a $3.6 Billion Valuation
item.description: Whoop, a startup that makes wearable health trackers, raised $200 million in financing led by SoftBank at a $3.6 billion valuation, making it the most valuable standalone human performance company in the world, according to a PR release from Whoop.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: What You Need to Know About Elizabeth Holmes’s Trial That Starts Today
item.description: Jury selection begins today for the criminal fraud trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of shuttered Silicon Valley biotech startup Theranos. Holmes’s net worth also grew to $4.5 billion, good enough for No. 1 on the Forbes list of America’s Richest Self-Made Women. Fall into a Theranos rabbit hole: The WSJ reporter who broke the story, John Carreyrou, wrote a riveting book about the fraud called Bad Blood. The downfall of Theranos may have briefly scared investors into looking closer at pitch decks, but it may take more than a conviction to change the Valley’s entrenched “fake it ’til you make it” mindset. Balwani’s lawyers called the claims “deeply offensive.”
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: China Limits Online Video Games to Three Hours a Week for Minors
item.description: All online video games are required to be connected to an “anti-addiction” system operated by the NPPA using real-name registration. We made a funny (and weirdly emotional) TikTok about the news. Want more? Tencent’s market cap has lost more than $400 billion since a February peak.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: EU Recommends Banning Unvaccinated American Tourists From Traveling to Europe
item.description: The European Council removed the US from the “safe list” of countries that can send tourists to the EU due to high Covid rates here in the States. While the EU recommended opening up its borders to American tourists in June, the US has yet to reciprocate for European visitors, angering the EU.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: August 30
item.description: Everything else:September begins on WednesdayBonnaroo is on ThursdayGet pumped for the long Labor Day weekend yeah that’s it.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 30
item.description: Stat: The only thing worse than LA road traffic is LA marine traffic. (Vox) Read: The economic case for bringing in as many refugees as possible.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Why Are Rent Prices Surging?
item.description: The No. 1 comeback story of the year isn’t jeans—it’s rental prices. Now, rent prices in 87 of the country’s 100 largest cities have fully returned to pre-pandemic levels.  The website Apartment List explained some of the trends behind the trend.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Oxygen Runs in Short Supply for Covid-19 Patients, Water Treatment, and Space Missions
item.description: Liquid oxygen is used to treat the water supply, but the city is running low because of the crush of Covid hospitalizations.   But diverting oxygen to hospitals to treat Covid-19 patients means it can’t be deployed for other uses. As if the Southeast US didn’t have enough to deal with already, hospitals are running low on oxygen for treating Covid-19 patients, and it’s causing ripple effects for other industries that use the stuff for their daily operations.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Powerfull Hurricane Ida Makes Landfall in Louisiana
item.description: As of late last night, the only power to the city was coming from generators. this is the beginning, not the end, of the Ida story. Hurricane Ida slammed into Louisiana on exactly the same date, Aug. 29, as Katrina did in 2005.  The entire city of New Orleans was left without power, according to the regional energy provider Entergy.  Looking ahead... If refineries suffer a direct hit, gas prices could rise by about 10 cents in many East Coast markets. And 60% of gasoline used on the East Coast comes from Gulf Coast refineries.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Why Are Rent Prices Surging?
item.description: Turns out the No. 1 comeback story of the year isn’t jeans—it’s rental prices.  Housing is too expensive: Skyrocketing housing prices are causing some would-be homeowners to choose renting instead. Now, rent prices in 87 of the country’s 100 largest cities have fully returned to pre-pandemic levels.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: August 30
item.description: Everything else:September begins on WednesdayBonnaroo is on ThursdayGet pumped for the long Labor Day weekend yeah that’s it.

item.title: Oxygen Runs in Short Supply for Covid-19 Patients, Water Treatment, and Space Missions
item.description: But diverting oxygen to hospitals to treat Covid-19 patients means it can’t be deployed for other uses. Because of higher Covid-19 hospitalizations, the city was running low on liquid oxygen, which is used to treat the water supply. As if the Southeast US didn’t have enough to deal with already, hospitals are running low on oxygen for treating Covid-19 patients, and it’s causing ripple effects for other industries that use the stuff for their daily operations.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Powerfull Hurricane Ida Makes Landfall in Louisiana
item.description: this is the beginning, not the end, of the Ida story. Hurricane Ida slammed into Louisiana on exactly the same date, Aug. 29, as Katrina did in 2005. If refineries suffer a direct hit, gas prices could rise by about 10 cents in many Eastern markets. As of late last night, the only power to the city was coming from generators.  The entire city of New Orleans was left without power, according to the regional energy provider Entergy.  Looking ahead...  Louisiana’s refineries make up almost 20% of the country’s total refining capacity.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Q&A With Paralympic Gold Medalist Mike Schultz
item.description: To learn about what it takes to be a Paralympic champion, we asked gold medal-winning snowboarder Mike Schultz what was harder: winning the gold or starting his company, BioDapt, which provides lower-limb prosthetics for action sports.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 28
item.description: (ABC News)  Read: Inside the daring mission by US special operations vets to rescue Afghan allies. Social media consultant Sarah Petite spoke to the WSJ about the new generation of stock-picking influencers who’ve taken over YouTube.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Support.com Becomes The Latest Meme Stock
item.description: SEC Chair Gary Gensler said his regulatory agency is looking into how apps like Robinhood gamify trading with features that encourage the kind of frenzied investing activity we’ve seen around meme stocks like Support. com is a relatively unknown software company, considering how high it must rank in Google search results.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Powell Signals the Fed Will Wind Down Stimulus Measures in the Coming Months
item.description: In a highly anticipated speech yesterday, the Fed Chair said that the economy has recovered enough that “it could be appropriate” to start slowing down some of the Fed’s pandemic-era stimulus measures.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: How Tim Cook Changed Apple in the 10 Years He's Been CEO
item.description: That’s right, Cook has been the CEO of Apple for exactly 10 years this week. Cook still has plenty of problems to deal with, from high-stakes legal challenges against Apple’s App Store policies to a more vocal workforce to thorny privacy questions. While the iPhone still reigns supreme, Apple has expanded its hardware lineup in the last decade and scored hits with the Apple Watch and AirPods. It also made a big move into services (Apple Pay, Apple Music, etc. Looking ahead... did (admittedly a low bar). What did your partner get you for your 10th anniversary?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Support.com Becomes The Latest Meme Stock
item.description: SEC Chair Gary Gensler said his regulatory agency is looking into how apps like Robinhood gamify trading with features that encourage the kind of frenzied investing activity we’ve seen around meme stocks like Support. com is a relatively unknown software company, considering how high it must rank in Google search results.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: ‘Monster’ Mike Schultz Talks the Paralympic Games, Winning Gold in 2018, and Disney Channel Original Movies
item.description: What’s more difficult: Winning a gold medal at the Paralympics or starting a company? But running a business or starting a business is an ongoing set of challenges. I'm going to have to go watch it again and refresh my memory.  To learn about what it takes to be a Paralympic champion, we chatted with gold medal-winning snowboarder Mike Schultz. After my injury in 2008, I really started spending a lot more time with the horses. What is something most people don't know about competing at the Paralympics? Yes, it's been a long time.  When I won gold and was able to stand on top of the podium and listen to the national anthem start playing, man, that is a very powerful moment that not many people get to experience.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Q&A With Paralympic Gold Medalist Mike Schultz
item.description: To learn about what it takes to be a Paralympic champion, we asked gold medal-winning snowboarder Mike Schultz what was harder: winning the gold or starting his company, BioDapt, which provides lower-limb prosthetics for action sports.

item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: How Tim Cook Changed Apple in the 10 Years He's Been CEO
item.description: That’s right, Cook has been the CEO of Apple for exactly 10 years this week. Cook still has plenty of problems to deal with, from high-stakes legal challenges against Apple’s App Store policies to a more vocal workforce to thorny privacy questions. While the iPhone still reigns supreme, Apple has expanded its hardware lineup in the last decade and scored hits with the Apple Watch and AirPods.  Apple’s annual revenue in 2011, when Cook took over, was $108.2 billion; in 2020 it made $274.5 billion. It also made a big move into services (Apple Pay, Apple Music, etc.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Same-day Streaming Causes Movie Piracy to Ramp Up
item.description: While streaming platforms may recoup some money lost to piracy via digital rentals and subscriber growth (which has boomed for Disney+, HBO Max, and Netflix), theaters won’t see a cent of that. Black Widow was the most pirated movie in the world for three weeks running after it was released on Disney+ and in theaters on July 9, according to piracy-monitoring site TorrentFreak. What pirated movies used to look like: shaky camcorder recordings of movies taken in theaters and uploaded to piracy sites. Black Widow, The Suicide Squad, Jungle Cruise, and other would-be blockbusters simultaneously debuted in theaters and on streaming services in summer 2021. Theater owners are blaming the recent phenomenon of same-day releases for a spike in piracy.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Powell Signals the Fed Will Wind Down Stimulus Measures in the Coming Months
item.description: In a highly anticipated speech yesterday, the Fed Chair said that the economy has recovered enough that “it could be appropriate” to start slowing down some of the Fed’s pandemic-era stimulus measures.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Make It Work
item.description: Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? I like my boss, but how do I get them to stop micromanaging me? Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Give a little grace, if you can afford it. Be one of the first subscribers to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources. When you get a new project, ask your boss, “What would it look like if this were done perfectly?” Does your boss know that their current style demotivates you? Ask Shane here. Finding ways to introduce resources like these can help to limit unnecessary micromanagement and strengthen leadership skills throughout your organization. —Rachel in FloridaThis seems like a fun one to crowdsource to Brew readers—anyone game to help Rachel out? HR Brew.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Happiness Expert Dr. Laurie Santos
item.description: But joking aside, I think one of the things you learn when you study primates in particular is that humans really are just animals ultimately.  The most important tip is realizing that rejection really hurts. On the one hand, pictures can help us remember things better, which helps us to access all our fondest moments. But the good news is that those self-reports are valid for happiness and well-being. Take time to write down the things you like about yourself, why you’re valued. So really the best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself. One of the great things about being the person who teaches a happiness class is that I have to practice what I preach.  The best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself, “How am I feeling right now?” But if taking pictures means that you're worrying about how your hair looks or forcing people out of the moment to take a picture, then they might not be such a good idea.   Santos was kind enough to grant us time during office hours to ask a few questions. Meet up with the people who really care about you, and if you can't meet up with them directly, then do some “social snacking” and just look at pictures of people who are close to you. That’ll allow you to have a memento that will help you remember after the fact.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 27
item.description: (BBC Future)  Read: How water shortages are brewing wars. Last week’s hack compromised the personal info of more than 50 million people.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Corporate America’s $50 Billion Pledge to Fight Against Racial Inequality
item.description: Last June, US corporations pledged to give a historic sum of money to projects addressing racial inequality following George Floyd’s murder.   14 months later, where and how has the money been spent? So far, 37 companies have confirmed disbursing at least $1.7 billion.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Peloton Shares Slide After Disappointing Quarter, Price Cut on Bike
item.description: Not even Cody Rigsby could cheer up Peloton after its latest earnings report. — NF before yesterday’s tumble.  After gaining more than 440% last year, shares have fallen more than 25% year-to-date...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Supreme Court Throws Out Biden's Eviction Moratorium
item.description: Big picture: The eviction moratorium was just Part 1 of a two-pronged approach by the government to help out renters during the pandemic. But because the latest moratorium was authorized by the CDC and not by Congress, it was on legal shaky footing. The Supreme Court put an end to the moratorium that protected renters from being evicted during the pandemic. — NF Looking ahead... Problem is, Part 2 has flopped harder than Amazon's Fire Phone.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Supreme Court Throws Out Biden's Eviction Moratorium
item.description: Big picture: The eviction moratorium was just Part 1 of a two-pronged approach by the government to help out renters during the pandemic. The Supreme Court put an end to the moratorium that protected renters from being evicted from their homes during the pandemic. But because the latest moratorium was authorized by the CDC and not by Congress, it was on legal shaky footing. Looking ahead... Problem is, Part 2 has flopped harder than the ESPN phone.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Peloton Shares Slide After Disappointing Quarter, Price Cut on Bike
item.description: Not even Cody Rigsby could cheer up Peloton after its latest earnings report. before yesterday’s tumble.  After gaining more than 440% last year, shares have fallen more than 25% year-to-date...
item.author: Neal Freyman
